review.title: Query Answering over Contextualized RDF/OWL Knowledge with Forall-Existential Bridge Rules: Attaining Decidability using Acyclicity (full version)
review.abstract: The recent outburst of context-dependent knowledge on the Semantic Web (SW) has led to the realization of the importance of the quads in the SW community. Quads, which extend a standard RDF triple, by adding a new parameter of the `context' of an RDF triple, thus informs a reasoner to distinguish between the knowledge in various contexts. Although this distinction separates the triples in an RDF graph into various contexts, and allows the reasoning to be decoupled across various contexts, bridge rules need to be provided for inter-operating the knowledge across these contexts. We call a set of quads together with the bridge rules, a quad-system. In this paper, we discuss the problem of query answering over quad-systems with expressive forall-existential bridge rules. It turns out the query answering over quad-systems is undecidable, in general. We derive a decidable class of quad-systems, namely context-acyclic quad-systems, for which query answering can be done using forward chaining. Tight bounds for data and combined complexity of query entailment has been established for the derived class.

metadata.title: Query Answering over Contextualized RDF Knowledge with Forall-Existential Bridge Rules: Attaining Decidability using Acyclicity (full version)

sections.text: ar Xiv: 140 6.08 93v1 [cs.LO] 3 JKeywords: Contextualized RDF / OWL knowledge, Contextualized response to queries, quads, Forall existential rules, Semantic Web, knowledge representation.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: One of the most important recent changes in the SW community is the transformation from a triple to a quad as the primary knowledge carrier. As a result, more and more triple stores are becoming quad stores. Some of the popular quad stores are also referred to as c: (s, p, o), where c is an identifier that stands for the context of the triple (s, p, o). Some recent initiatives in this direction have also expanded existing formats such as N-Triples to N-Quads. (BTC 2012) have all been published in N-Quads format.1 http: / / virtuoso.openlinksw.com / rf-ad-store / http: / / http: / / http: / / http: / / http: www.openlinksw.com / http: / / http: / http: / / http: / http: / / http: / / http: / / www.quad-stores-stores).

sections.heading: 2 Contextualized Quad-Systems
sections.text: In this section we formalize the concept of a quad system and its semantics. For each vector or sequence x we denote the number of symbols in x, and by {x} the set of symbols in x. For all sets A and B, A → B denotes the set of all functions from set A to set B. Given the set of URIs U, the set of empty nodes B and the set of letters L, the set of (RDF) constants. Each (s, p, o) set C · C · C · C · C is a generalized set of RDF triples. A quad is a tuple of the form c: (s, p, o), where (s, o) the (s, o) is a triple and c) is a URI4, which denotes the context of the RDF triples.

sections.heading: 4 Context Acyclic Quad-Systems: A decidable class
sections.text: In the previous section, we have seen that the answer to unrestricted quad systems in general cannot be deciphered. In the following, we define a class of quad systems for which the query implementation is decided.The class has the property that algorithms based on forward concatenation are in the realm of Datalog +.Consider a BR r of the form: c1: t1 (x, z), c2: t2 (x, z), c3: t3 (x, y), c4: t4 (x, y).Since such a rule is trigger propagation of knowledge in a quad system, specifically triples from the target contexts c3, c4 in a shared system.

sections.heading: 6 Summary and Conclusion
sections.text: We show that the problem is generally indecipherable and present a decideable class called contextual acyclic quad systems. Table 1 summarizes the most important results achieved. We can show that the concept of context cyclicality introduced in Section 4 can be used to expand the currently established tools for context-based thinking to provide support for expressive BRs with conjuction and existentials with determinability guarantees. We consider the results obtained in this paper as a general basis for context-based thinking and query responses to context-based RDF knowledge formats such as quads and can easily be used to expand existing quad stores to cooperate for all existential BRs of the form (1).

referenceMentions.context: One of the main benefits of quads over triples are that they allow users to specify various attributes of meta-knowledge that further qualify knowledge [8], and also allow users to query for this meta knowledge [29].
Besides the above flexibility, bridge rules [4] can be provided for inter-interoperating the knowledge in different contexts.
In this work, we consider forall-existential bridge rules that allows conjunctions and existential quantifiers in them, and hence is more expressive than those, in DDL [4] and McCarthy et al.
For query answering, we use the notion of a distributed chase, which is an extension of a standard chase [22, 1] that is widely used in databases and KR for the same.
For query answering, we use the notion of a distributed chase, which is an extension of a standard chase [22, 1] that is widely used in databases and KR for the same.
Some of the alternatives for the local semantics satisfying the above mentioned criterion are Simple, RDF, RDFS [19], OWL-Horst [20] etc.

dChase of a Quad-System In order to do query answering over a quad-system, we employ what has been called in the literature, a chase [22, 1], specifically, we adopt notion of the skolem chase given in Marnette [26] and Cuenca Grau et al [9].

Contexts and Distributed Logics The work on contexts began in the 80s when McCarthy [21] proposed context as a solution to the generality problem in AI.
After this various studies about logics of contexts mainly in the field of KR was done by Guha [28], Distributed First Order Logics by Ghidini et al.
[14] and Local Model Semantics by Giunchiglia et al.
Some of the initial works on contexts relevant to semantic web were the ones like Distributed Description Logics [4] by Borgida et al.
, E-connections [25] by Kutz et al.
, Context-OWL [5] by Bouqet et al.
, and the work of CKR [30, 23] by Serafini et al.

∀∃ rules, TGDs, Datalog+- rules Query answering over rules with universal existential quantifiers in the context of databases/KR, where these rules are called tuple generating dependencies (TGDs)/Datalog+- rules, was done by Beeri and Vardi [3] even in the early 80s, where the authors show that the query entailment problem in general is undecidable.

metadata.abstractText: The recent outburst of context-dependent knowledge on the Semantic Web (SW) has led to the realization of the importance of the quads in the SW community. Quads, which extend a standard RDF triple, by adding a new parameter of the ‘context’ of an RDF triple, thus informs a reasoner to distinguish between the knowledge in various contexts. Although this distinction separates the triples in an RDF graph into various contexts, and allows the reasoning to be decoupled across various contexts, bridge rules need to be provided for inter-operating the knowledge across these contexts. We call a set of quads together with the bridge rules, a quad-system. In this paper, we discuss the problem of query answering over quad-systems with expressive forall-existential bridge rules. It turns out the query answering over quad-systems is undecidable, in general. We derive a decidable class of quad-systems, namely context-acyclic quadsystems, for which query answering can be done using forward chaining. Tight bounds for data and combined complexity of query entailment has been established for the derived class.
